funder.name: The Bavarian Ministry of Education and Culture, Sciences and Arts
German Federal Ministry of Education and Research

abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We present the first comprehensive <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcoding study of German reptiles and amphibians representing likewise the first on the European herpetofauna. A total of 248 barcodes for all native species and subspecies in the country and a few additional taxa were obtained in the framework of the projects ‘Barcoding Fauna Bavarica’ (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BFB</jats:styled-content>) and ‘German Barcode of Life’ (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GBOL</jats:styled-content>). In contrast to many invertebrate groups, the success rate of the identification of mitochondrial lineages representing species via <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcode was almost 100% because no cases of Barcode Index Number (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>) sharing were detected within German native reptiles and amphibians. However, as expected, a reliable identification of the hybridogenetic species complex in the frog genus <jats:italic>Pelophylax</jats:italic> was not possible. Deep conspecific lineages resulting in the identification of more than one <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content> were found in <jats:italic>Lissotriton vulgaris</jats:italic>,<jats:italic> Natrix natrix</jats:italic> and the hybridogenetic <jats:italic>Pelophylax</jats:italic> complex. A high variety of lineages with different <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>s was also found in the barcodes of wall lizards (<jats:italic>Podarcis muralis</jats:italic>), confirming the existence of many introduced lineages and the frequent occurrence of multiple introductions. Besides the reliable species identification of all life stages and even of tissue remains, our study highlights other potential applications of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcoding concerning German amphibians and reptiles, such as the detection of allochthonous lineages, monitoring of gene flow and also noninvasive sampling via environmental <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>. <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcoding based on <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">COI</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> has now proven to be a reliable and efficient tool for studying most amphibians and reptiles as it is already for many other organism groups in zoology.</jats:p>
title: Comprehensive DNA barcoding of the herpetofauna of Germany
